Aviv","title":"Rachel Aviv is a staff writer at The New Yorker. She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. He also reviews movies for NPR’s “Fresh Air.” Previously, he was the film critic at the Los Angeles *Times* and the chief film critic at *Variety*. His book “[FilmCraft: Editing](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilmCraft-Editing-Justin-Chang\u002Fdp\u002F0240818644)” was published in 2011. Chang serves as the chair of the National Society of Film Critics and the secretary of the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, and is a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee. He teaches at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California. In 2024, he won the Pulitzer Prize for criticism, for his writing about film at the Los Angeles *Times*.","socialMedia":[],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}},{"node":{"__typename":"Contributor","id":"5909e8e68b51cf59fc4246ac","url":"contributors\u002Frichard-brody","name":"Richard Brody","title":"Richard Brody, a film critic, began writing for *The New Yorker* in 1999. He is the author of [“Everything Is Cinema: The Working Life of Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0805080155\u002F).”","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"59097b758b51cf59fc423c61","filename":"brody-richard.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2017\u002F05\u002F03\u002F59097b758b51cf59fc423c60_brody-richard.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Richard Brody, a film critic at *The New Yorker*, began contributing in 1999. For his column, [The Front Row](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row), he has reviewed blockbusters, such as “[Top Gun: Maverick](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Ftop-gun-maverick-reviewed-tom-cruise-takes-empty-thrills-to-new-heights)”; international movies, such as “[Parasite](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-parasite-falls-short-of-greatness)”; independent films, including “[Lady Bird](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Frichard-brody\u002Fgreta-gerwigs-exquisite-flawed-lady-bird)”; and documentaries, such as “[Let It Be](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-hindsight-distorts-our-view-of-the-beatles-in-let-it-be),” the 1970 film about the Beatles. His roundups have included the [best performances of the twenty-first century](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fthe-best-movie-performances-of-the-century-so-far) and the [best documentaries of all time](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fsixty-two-films-that-shaped-the-art-of-documentary-filmmaking). Brody has also contributed articles about directors such as [Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpostscript\u002Fjean-luc-godard-was-cinemas-north-star) and [Wes Anderson](http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2009\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fwild-wild-wes). Previously, she served as an editor at Slate and at *Time*. For *The New Yorker*, Winter has [reported](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-the-life-of-the-mother-might-mean-in-a-post-roe-america) [extensively](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fthe-supreme-court-decision-that-defined-abortion-rights-for-thirty-years) on the [landscape](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fthe-dobbs-decision-has-unleashed-legal-chaos-for-doctors-and-patients) for [reproductive rights](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fthe-fight-over-ivf-is-only-beginning) in the U.S. after the [overturning](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fwhats-missing-from-the-drafted-decision-to-overturn-roe-v-wade) of Roe v. Wade, and frequently contributes essays on books, culture, and current affairs. She has written about topics including [gentle parenting](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Funder-review\u002Fthe-harsh-realm-of-gentle-parenting), [middle-school culture wars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-meltdown-at-a-middle-school-in-a-liberal-town), [early literacy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-vibes-based-literacy), [queer children’s books](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Flgbt-books-kids-ban), and [postpartum psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-we-still-dont-understand-about-postpartum-psychosis). Winter is the author of the novels “[The Fourth Child](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0062971557\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Break in Case of Emergency](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F110191193X\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20).” She lives with her children in western Previously, he was the deputy editor of *Transition*, a journal of race and culture based at the W. E. B. Du Bois Research Institute at Harvard University. His writing has also appeared in a number of magazines and a handful of books, including “[Shake It Up: Great American Writing on Rock and Pop from Elvis to Jay Rosner is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*. She has been covering food for more than a decade as a writer and editor, and has received multiple James Beard Awards, including, in 2025, for her [Profile of the food personality Padma Lakshmi](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fprofiles\u002Fpadma-lakshmi-walks-into-a-bar), and, in 2024, for her weekly restaurant-review column, [The Food Scene](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Ffood-scene). In 2022, Rosner was a National Magazine Award finalist, for pieces on [how to cook with a microwave](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fkitchen-notes\u002Flearning-to-love-my-microwave), the CNN series “[Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fthe-timeless-fantasy-of-stanley-tucci-eating-italian-food),” and [how to get a table at Carbone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fhow-to-get-a-table-at-carbone). Rosner has worked at *Saveur* and *New York* magazine, launched the seminal food site Eat Me Daily, and served as a cookbook editor. Before joining *The New Yorker*, she was the executive editor of Eater, where she founded the publication’s James Beard- and National Magazine Award-winning features ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"5e7bc3aeba0e6f0009421c5b","filename":"RachelSyme.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F25\u002F5e7bc3aece97b85da38b2206_RachelSyme.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Syme, a staff writer, has covered Hollywood, theatre, fashion, television, literature, style, and other cultural subjects for *The New Yorker* since 2012. Her contributions include profiles of the actors [Carol Burnett](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2025\u002F10\u002F06\u002Fcarol-burnett-profile), [Natasha Lyonne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F11\u002Fin-russian-doll-natasha-lyonne-barrels-into-the-past), [Adam Scott](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fadam-scott-profile), and [Sarah Jessica Parker](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F06\u002F26\u002Fsarah-jessica-parker-profile); the director [Sofia Coppola](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fsofia-coppola-profile); the fashion designer [Thom Browne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F09\u002F25\u002Fhow-thom-brownes-gray-suit-conquered-american-fashion); the Netflix executive [Bela Bajaria](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F01\u002F16\u002Fhow-much-more-netflix-can-the-world-absorb-bela-bajaria); the theatre director [Rachel Chavkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fbehind-the-scenes-of-a-short-lived-broadway-musical); the perfumer [Francis Kurkdjian](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F09\u002F23\u002Ffrancis-kurkdjian-perfume-baccarat-rouge); the [creators of “PEN15”](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fthe-women-behind-the-thirteen-year-olds-of-pen15); and the [makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F07\u002Fback-to-school-with-mario-dedivanovic); an homage to the food writer [Laurie Colwin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F18\u002Flaurie-colwins-recipe-for-being-yourself-in-the-kitchen); a look into [Nora Ephron](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F08\u002F22\u002Fthe-nora-ephron-we-forget)’s verbal prowess; an essay on the rise of [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F11\u002F27\u002Fmy-name-is-barbra-streisand-memoir-review); an exploration of “[bathfluencers](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fon-and-off-the-avenue\u002Fthe-age-of-bathfluence)”; an interactive feature on [the art of the Hollywood memoir](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Fpage-turner\u002Fcelebrity-memoirs-book-reviews); conversations with [Lena Dunham](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Flena-dunhams-change-of-pace), [Jamie Lee Curtis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fjamie-lee-curtis-has-never-worked-hard-a-day-in-her-life), [Rick Steves](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Frick-steves-says-hold-on-to-your-travel-dreams), [Kate Berlant](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fkate-berlant-has-nothing-to-confess), [Parker Posey](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fparker-posey-is-dead-serious), [Patti LuPone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fpatti-lupone-live-from-her-basement), [Mandy Patinkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fmandy-patinkin-is-still-singing), and [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fbarbra-streisand-can-hear-herself-again); and short profiles of [Kirsten Dunst](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fkirsten-dunsts-feminine-urges), [Cynthia Nixon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fcynthia-nixons-emily-thing), and [Anna Deavere Smith](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fanna-deavere-smith-contains-multitudes). She is a regular contributor to the magazine’s On and Off the Avenue column.\n\nSyme’s cultural criticism and reported features, which focus primarily on the intersections of women’s lives, artistic production, history, and fame, have also appeared in the *Times Magazine*, *New York*, *Vogue*, *Rolling Stone*, and *Vanity Fair*, among other publications. She is the author of “[Syme’s Letter Writer](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSymes-Letter-Writer-Correspondence-Imaginable\u002Fdp\u002F059323510X)” (2025), about the joys of handwritten correspondence, and the narrative-nonfiction work “Magpie” (2026). His column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), examines the people and platforms shaping the Internet. His books include “[Filterworld: How Algorithms Flattened Culture](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281).” ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"60d4ac8925fa556303904def","filename":"kyle_chayka.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2021\u002F06\u002F24\u002F60d4ac8925fa556303904dee_kyle_chayka.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Kyle Chayka is a staff writer at *The New Yorker* covering technology and Internet culture. In his column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), he has explored why [the Internet isn’t fun anymore](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fwhy-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore), examined whether [A.I. art steals from artists](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fis-ai-art-stealing-from-artists), and covered [TikTok’s role in the vibes revival](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fcultural-comment\u002Ftiktok-and-the-vibes-revival). Chayka, who first contributed to *The New Yorker* in 2013, has also written for *The New Republic*, the New York *Times Magazine*, and *Harper’s*, among other publications. His reporting on tourism in Iceland was included in “[The Best American Travel Writing 2020](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FBest-American-Travel-Writing-2020\u002Fdp\u002F0358362032).” Chayka’s first nonfiction book, “[The Longing for Less](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLonging-Less-Living-Minimalism\u002Fdp\u002F163557210X),” a history of minimalism, was published in 2020. His second book, “[Filterworld](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=2TWV5H73GY78G&keywords=filterworld+book&qid=1706824552&sprefix=filterworld+book%2Caps%2C259&sr=8-1),” which explores the impact of digital algorithms on culture, was published in 2024. Chayka began his career in 2010, as a visual-art critic for the Web site Aviv","title":"Rachel Aviv is a staff writer at The New Yorker. She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. She is a former writer for “Saturday Night Live” and “Rugrats.” Her books include the novels “[Him Her Him Again the End of Him](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0743296249\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Starting from Happy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1439101299\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” both of which were finalists for the Thurber Prize; numerous children’s books, among them “[Now Everybody Really Hates Me](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0064434400\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=2&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Meet My Staff](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0060274840\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=3&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[Tired Town](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FTired-Town-Patricia-Marx\u002Fdp\u002F1250859123\u002F)”; and nonfiction books, including “[Let’s Be Less Stupid: An Attempt to Maintain My Mental Faculties](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1455554960\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=4&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Why Don’t You Write My Eulogy Now So I Can Correct It?: A Mother’s Suggestions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1250301963\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=5&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[You Can Only Yell at Me for One Thing at a Time: Rules for Couples](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FYou-Only-Yell-Thing-Time\u002Fdp\u002F1250225132),” illustrated by Roz Chast.\n\nMarx was the first woman elected to the *Harvard Lampoon*. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. His book “[FilmCraft: Editing](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilmCraft-Editing-Justin-Chang\u002Fdp\u002F0240818644)” was published in 2011. Chang serves as the chair of the National Society of Film Critics and the secretary of the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, and is a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee. He teaches at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California. For his column, [The Front Row](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row), he has reviewed blockbusters, such as “[Top Gun: Maverick](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Ftop-gun-maverick-reviewed-tom-cruise-takes-empty-thrills-to-new-heights)”; international movies, such as “[Parasite](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-parasite-falls-short-of-greatness)”; independent films, including “[Lady Bird](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Frichard-brody\u002Fgreta-gerwigs-exquisite-flawed-lady-bird)”; and documentaries, such as “[Let It Be](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-hindsight-distorts-our-view-of-the-beatles-in-let-it-be),” the 1970 film about the Beatles. His roundups have included the [best performances of the twenty-first century](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fthe-best-movie-performances-of-the-century-so-far) and the [best documentaries of all time](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fsixty-two-films-that-shaped-the-art-of-documentary-filmmaking). Brody has also contributed articles about directors such as [Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpostscript\u002Fjean-luc-godard-was-cinemas-north-star) and [Wes Anderson](http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2009\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fwild-wild-wes). He is the author of the book “[Everything Is Cinema: The Working Life of Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0805080155)” and is at work on a book about the lasting influence of the French New Wave.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"tnyfrontrow","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"2025-in-review","name":"2025 in Review"},"channels":[{"name":"2025 in Review"},{"name":"The Current Cinema"},{"name":"The Front Row"}],"hed":"The Best Films of 2025","dek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","promoHed":"The Best Films of 2025","promoDek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","url":"culture\u002F2025-in-review\u002Fthe-best-films-of-2025","rubric":"","lede":{"bookMarkedUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.newyorker.com\u002Fphotos\u002F693208dc342b18a8b4bf3297\u002Fmaster\u002Fpass\u002FBest%20Movies%201%20(1).gif","altText":"Animation of a film reel rolling down film. For *The New Yorker*, Winter has [reported](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-the-life-of-the-mother-might-mean-in-a-post-roe-america) [extensively](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fthe-supreme-court-decision-that-defined-abortion-rights-for-thirty-years) on the [landscape](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fthe-dobbs-decision-has-unleashed-legal-chaos-for-doctors-and-patients) for [reproductive rights](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fthe-fight-over-ivf-is-only-beginning) in the U.S. after the [overturning](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fwhats-missing-from-the-drafted-decision-to-overturn-roe-v-wade) of Roe v. Wade, and frequently contributes essays on books, culture, and current affairs. She has written about topics including [gentle parenting](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Funder-review\u002Fthe-harsh-realm-of-gentle-parenting), [middle-school culture wars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-meltdown-at-a-middle-school-in-a-liberal-town), [early literacy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-vibes-based-literacy), [queer children’s books](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Flgbt-books-kids-ban), and [postpartum psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-we-still-dont-understand-about-postpartum-psychosis). Winter is the author of the novels “[The Fourth Child](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0062971557\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Break in Rosner is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*. She has been covering food for more than a decade as a writer and editor, and has received multiple James Beard Awards, including, in 2025, for her [Profile of the food personality Padma Lakshmi](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fprofiles\u002Fpadma-lakshmi-walks-into-a-bar), and, in 2024, for her weekly restaurant-review column, [The Food Scene](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Ffood-scene). In 2022, Rosner was a National Magazine Award finalist, for pieces on [how to cook with a microwave](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fkitchen-notes\u002Flearning-to-love-my-microwave), the CNN series “[Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fthe-timeless-fantasy-of-stanley-tucci-eating-italian-food),” and [how to get a table at Carbone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fhow-to-get-a-table-at-carbone). Rosner has worked at *Saveur* and *New York* magazine, launched the seminal food site Eat Me Daily, and served as a cookbook editor. Before joining *The New Yorker*, she was the executive editor of Eater, where she founded the publication’s James Beard- and National Magazine Award-winning features ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"5e7bc3aeba0e6f0009421c5b","filename":"RachelSyme.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F25\u002F5e7bc3aece97b85da38b2206_RachelSyme.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Syme, a staff writer, has covered Hollywood, theatre, fashion, television, literature, style, and other cultural subjects for *The New Yorker* since 2012. Her contributions include profiles of the actors [Carol Burnett](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2025\u002F10\u002F06\u002Fcarol-burnett-profile), [Natasha Lyonne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F11\u002Fin-russian-doll-natasha-lyonne-barrels-into-the-past), [Adam Scott](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fadam-scott-profile), and [Sarah Jessica Parker](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F06\u002F26\u002Fsarah-jessica-parker-profile); the director [Sofia Coppola](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fsofia-coppola-profile); the fashion designer [Thom Browne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F09\u002F25\u002Fhow-thom-brownes-gray-suit-conquered-american-fashion); the Netflix executive [Bela Bajaria](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F01\u002F16\u002Fhow-much-more-netflix-can-the-world-absorb-bela-bajaria); the theatre director [Rachel Chavkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fbehind-the-scenes-of-a-short-lived-broadway-musical); the perfumer [Francis Kurkdjian](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F09\u002F23\u002Ffrancis-kurkdjian-perfume-baccarat-rouge); the [creators of “PEN15”](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fthe-women-behind-the-thirteen-year-olds-of-pen15); and the [makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F07\u002Fback-to-school-with-mario-dedivanovic); an homage to the food writer [Laurie Colwin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F18\u002Flaurie-colwins-recipe-for-being-yourself-in-the-kitchen); a look into [Nora Ephron](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F08\u002F22\u002Fthe-nora-ephron-we-forget)’s verbal prowess; an essay on the rise of [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F11\u002F27\u002Fmy-name-is-barbra-streisand-memoir-review); an exploration of “[bathfluencers](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fon-and-off-the-avenue\u002Fthe-age-of-bathfluence)”; an interactive feature on [the art of the Hollywood memoir](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Fpage-turner\u002Fcelebrity-memoirs-book-reviews); conversations with [Lena Dunham](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Flena-dunhams-change-of-pace), [Jamie Lee Curtis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fjamie-lee-curtis-has-never-worked-hard-a-day-in-her-life), [Rick Steves](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Frick-steves-says-hold-on-to-your-travel-dreams), [Kate Berlant](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fkate-berlant-has-nothing-to-confess), [Parker Posey](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fparker-posey-is-dead-serious), [Patti LuPone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fpatti-lupone-live-from-her-basement), [Mandy Patinkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fmandy-patinkin-is-still-singing), and [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fbarbra-streisand-can-hear-herself-again); and short profiles of [Kirsten Dunst](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fkirsten-dunsts-feminine-urges), [Cynthia Nixon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fcynthia-nixons-emily-thing), and [Anna Deavere Smith](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fanna-deavere-smith-contains-multitudes). She is a regular contributor to the magazine’s On and Off the Avenue column.\n\nSyme’s cultural criticism and reported features, which focus primarily on the intersections of women’s lives, artistic production, history, and fame, have also appeared in the *Times Magazine*, *New York*, *Vogue*, *Rolling Stone*, and *Vanity Fair*, among other publications. She is the author of “[Syme’s Letter Writer](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSymes-Letter-Writer-Correspondence-Imaginable\u002Fdp\u002F059323510X)” (2025), about the joys of handwritten correspondence, and the narrative-nonfiction work “Magpie” (2026). His books include “[Filterworld: How Algorithms Flattened Culture](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281).” ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"60d4ac8925fa556303904def","filename":"kyle_chayka.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2021\u002F06\u002F24\u002F60d4ac8925fa556303904dee_kyle_chayka.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Kyle Chayka is a staff writer at *The New Yorker* covering technology and Internet culture. In his column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), he has explored why [the Internet isn’t fun anymore](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fwhy-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore), examined whether [A.I. art steals from artists](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fis-ai-art-stealing-from-artists), and covered [TikTok’s role in the vibes revival](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fcultural-comment\u002Ftiktok-and-the-vibes-revival). Chayka, who first contributed to *The New Yorker* in 2013, has also written for *The New Republic*, the New York *Times Magazine*, and *Harper’s*, among other publications. His reporting on tourism in Iceland was included in “[The Best American Travel Writing 2020](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FBest-American-Travel-Writing-2020\u002Fdp\u002F0358362032).” Chayka’s first nonfiction book, “[The Longing for Less](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLonging-Less-Living-Minimalism\u002Fdp\u002F163557210X),” a history of minimalism, was published in 2020. His second book, “[Filterworld](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=2TWV5H73GY78G&keywords=filterworld+book&qid=1706824552&sprefix=filterworld+book%2Caps%2C259&sr=8-1),” which explores the impact of digital algorithms on culture, was published in 2024. Chayka began his career in 2010, as a visual-art critic for the Web site She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. She is a former writer for “Saturday Night Live” and “Rugrats.” Her books include the novels “[Him Her Him Again the End of Him](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0743296249\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Starting from Happy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1439101299\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” both of which were finalists for the Thurber Prize; numerous children’s books, among them “[Now Everybody Really Hates Me](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0064434400\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=2&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Meet My Staff](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0060274840\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=3&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[Tired Town](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FTired-Town-Patricia-Marx\u002Fdp\u002F1250859123\u002F)”; and nonfiction books, including “[Let’s Be Less Stupid: An Attempt to Maintain My Mental Faculties](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1455554960\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=4&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Why Don’t You Write My Eulogy Now So I Can Correct It?: A Mother’s Suggestions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1250301963\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=5&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[You Can Only Yell at Me for One Thing at a Time: Rules for Couples](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FYou-Only-Yell-Thing-Time\u002Fdp\u002F1250225132),” illustrated by Roz Chast.\n\nMarx was the first woman elected to the *Harvard Lampoon*. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. Chang serves as the chair of the National Society of Film Critics and the secretary of the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, and is a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee. His roundups have included the [best performances of the twenty-first century](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fthe-best-movie-performances-of-the-century-so-far) and the [best documentaries of all time](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fsixty-two-films-that-shaped-the-art-of-documentary-filmmaking). Brody has also contributed articles about directors such as [Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpostscript\u002Fjean-luc-godard-was-cinemas-north-star) and [Wes Anderson](http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2009\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fwild-wild-wes). Previously, she served as an editor at Slate and at *Time*. For *The New Yorker*, Winter has [reported](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-the-life-of-the-mother-might-mean-in-a-post-roe-america) [extensively](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fthe-supreme-court-decision-that-defined-abortion-rights-for-thirty-years) on the [landscape](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fthe-dobbs-decision-has-unleashed-legal-chaos-for-doctors-and-patients) for [reproductive rights](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fthe-fight-over-ivf-is-only-beginning) in the U.S. after the [overturning](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fwhats-missing-from-the-drafted-decision-to-overturn-roe-v-wade) of Roe v. Wade, and frequently contributes essays on books, culture, and current affairs. She has written about topics including [gentle parenting](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Funder-review\u002Fthe-harsh-realm-of-gentle-parenting), [middle-school culture wars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-meltdown-at-a-middle-school-in-a-liberal-town), [early literacy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-vibes-based-literacy), [queer children’s books](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Flgbt-books-kids-ban), and [postpartum psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-we-still-dont-understand-about-postpartum-psychosis). Winter is the author of the novels “[The Fourth Child](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0062971557\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Break in Rosner is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*. She has been covering food for more than a decade as a writer and editor, and has received multiple James Beard Awards, including, in 2025, for her [Profile of the food personality Padma Lakshmi](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fprofiles\u002Fpadma-lakshmi-walks-into-a-bar), and, in 2024, for her weekly restaurant-review column, [The Food Scene](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Ffood-scene). In 2022, Rosner was a National Magazine Award finalist, for pieces on [how to cook with a microwave](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fkitchen-notes\u002Flearning-to-love-my-microwave), the CNN series “[Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fthe-timeless-fantasy-of-stanley-tucci-eating-italian-food),” and [how to get a table at Carbone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fhow-to-get-a-table-at-carbone). Rosner has worked at *Saveur* and *New York* magazine, launched the seminal food site Eat Me Daily, and served as a cookbook editor. Before joining *The New Yorker*, she was the executive editor of Eater, where she founded the publication’s James Beard- and National Magazine Award-winning features ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"5e7bc3aeba0e6f0009421c5b","filename":"RachelSyme.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F25\u002F5e7bc3aece97b85da38b2206_RachelSyme.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Syme, a staff writer, has covered Hollywood, theatre, fashion, television, literature, style, and other cultural subjects for *The New Yorker* since 2012. Her contributions include profiles of the actors [Carol Burnett](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2025\u002F10\u002F06\u002Fcarol-burnett-profile), [Natasha Lyonne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F11\u002Fin-russian-doll-natasha-lyonne-barrels-into-the-past), [Adam Scott](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fadam-scott-profile), and [Sarah Jessica Parker](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F06\u002F26\u002Fsarah-jessica-parker-profile); the director [Sofia Coppola](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fsofia-coppola-profile); the fashion designer [Thom Browne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F09\u002F25\u002Fhow-thom-brownes-gray-suit-conquered-american-fashion); the Netflix executive [Bela Bajaria](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F01\u002F16\u002Fhow-much-more-netflix-can-the-world-absorb-bela-bajaria); the theatre director [Rachel Chavkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fbehind-the-scenes-of-a-short-lived-broadway-musical); the perfumer [Francis Kurkdjian](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F09\u002F23\u002Ffrancis-kurkdjian-perfume-baccarat-rouge); the [creators of “PEN15”](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fthe-women-behind-the-thirteen-year-olds-of-pen15); and the [makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F07\u002Fback-to-school-with-mario-dedivanovic); an homage to the food writer [Laurie Colwin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F18\u002Flaurie-colwins-recipe-for-being-yourself-in-the-kitchen); a look into [Nora Ephron](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F08\u002F22\u002Fthe-nora-ephron-we-forget)’s verbal prowess; an essay on the rise of [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F11\u002F27\u002Fmy-name-is-barbra-streisand-memoir-review); an exploration of “[bathfluencers](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fon-and-off-the-avenue\u002Fthe-age-of-bathfluence)”; an interactive feature on [the art of the Hollywood memoir](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Fpage-turner\u002Fcelebrity-memoirs-book-reviews); conversations with [Lena Dunham](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Flena-dunhams-change-of-pace), [Jamie Lee Curtis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fjamie-lee-curtis-has-never-worked-hard-a-day-in-her-life), [Rick Steves](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Frick-steves-says-hold-on-to-your-travel-dreams), [Kate Berlant](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fkate-berlant-has-nothing-to-confess), [Parker Posey](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fparker-posey-is-dead-serious), [Patti LuPone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fpatti-lupone-live-from-her-basement), [Mandy Patinkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fmandy-patinkin-is-still-singing), and [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fbarbra-streisand-can-hear-herself-again); and short profiles of [Kirsten Dunst](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fkirsten-dunsts-feminine-urges), [Cynthia Nixon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fcynthia-nixons-emily-thing), and [Anna Deavere Smith](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fanna-deavere-smith-contains-multitudes). She is a regular contributor to the magazine’s On and Off the Avenue column.\n\nSyme’s cultural criticism and reported features, which focus primarily on the intersections of women’s lives, artistic production, history, and fame, have also appeared in the *Times Magazine*, *New York*, *Vogue*, *Rolling Stone*, and *Vanity Fair*, among other publications. She is the author of “[Syme’s Letter Writer](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSymes-Letter-Writer-Correspondence-Imaginable\u002Fdp\u002F059323510X)” (2025), about the joys of handwritten correspondence, and the narrative-nonfiction work “Magpie” (2026). In his column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), he has explored why [the Internet isn’t fun anymore](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fwhy-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore), examined whether [A.I. art steals from artists](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fis-ai-art-stealing-from-artists), and covered [TikTok’s role in the vibes revival](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fcultural-comment\u002Ftiktok-and-the-vibes-revival). Chayka, who first contributed to *The New Yorker* in 2013, has also written for *The New Republic*, the New York *Times Magazine*, and *Harper’s*, among other publications. His reporting on tourism in Iceland was included in “[The Best American Travel Writing 2020](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FBest-American-Travel-Writing-2020\u002Fdp\u002F0358362032).” Chayka’s first nonfiction book, “[The Longing for Less](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLonging-Less-Living-Minimalism\u002Fdp\u002F163557210X),” a history of minimalism, was published in 2020. His second book, “[Filterworld](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=2TWV5H73GY78G&keywords=filterworld+book&qid=1706824552&sprefix=filterworld+book%2Caps%2C259&sr=8-1),” which explores the impact of digital algorithms on culture, was published in 2024. Chayka began his career in 2010, as a visual-art critic for the Web site She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. His book “[FilmCraft: Editing](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilmCraft-Editing-Justin-Chang\u002Fdp\u002F0240818644)” was published in 2011. Chang serves as the chair of the National Society of Film Critics and the secretary of the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, and is a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee. He teaches at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California. For his column, [The Front Row](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row), he has reviewed blockbusters, such as “[Top Gun: Maverick](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Ftop-gun-maverick-reviewed-tom-cruise-takes-empty-thrills-to-new-heights)”; international movies, such as “[Parasite](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-parasite-falls-short-of-greatness)”; independent films, including “[Lady Bird](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Frichard-brody\u002Fgreta-gerwigs-exquisite-flawed-lady-bird)”; and documentaries, such as “[Let It Be](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-hindsight-distorts-our-view-of-the-beatles-in-let-it-be),” the 1970 film about the Beatles. His roundups have included the [best performances of the twenty-first century](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fthe-best-movie-performances-of-the-century-so-far) and the [best documentaries of all time](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fsixty-two-films-that-shaped-the-art-of-documentary-filmmaking). Brody has also contributed articles about directors such as [Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpostscript\u002Fjean-luc-godard-was-cinemas-north-star) and [Wes Anderson](http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2009\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fwild-wild-wes). He is the author of the book “[Everything Is Cinema: The Working Life of Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0805080155)” and is at work on a book about the lasting influence of the French New Wave.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"tnyfrontrow","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"2025-in-review","name":"2025 in Review"},"channels":[{"name":"2025 in Review"},{"name":"The Current Cinema"},{"name":"The Front Row"}],"hed":"The Best Films of 2025","dek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","promoHed":"The Best Films of 2025","promoDek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","url":"culture\u002F2025-in-review\u002Fthe-best-films-of-2025","rubric":"","lede":{"bookMarkedUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.newyorker.com\u002Fphotos\u002F693208dc342b18a8b4bf3297\u002Fmaster\u002Fpass\u002FBest%20Movies%201%20(1).gif","altText":"Animation of a film reel rolling down film. Previously, she served as an editor at Slate and at *Time*. For *The New Yorker*, Winter has [reported](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-the-life-of-the-mother-might-mean-in-a-post-roe-america) [extensively](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fthe-supreme-court-decision-that-defined-abortion-rights-for-thirty-years) on the [landscape](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fthe-dobbs-decision-has-unleashed-legal-chaos-for-doctors-and-patients) for [reproductive rights](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fthe-fight-over-ivf-is-only-beginning) in the U.S. after the [overturning](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fwhats-missing-from-the-drafted-decision-to-overturn-roe-v-wade) of Roe v. Wade, and frequently contributes essays on books, culture, and current affairs. She has written about topics including [gentle parenting](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Funder-review\u002Fthe-harsh-realm-of-gentle-parenting), [middle-school culture wars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-meltdown-at-a-middle-school-in-a-liberal-town), [early literacy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-vibes-based-literacy), [queer children’s books](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Flgbt-books-kids-ban), and [postpartum psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-we-still-dont-understand-about-postpartum-psychosis). Winter is the author of the novels “[The Fourth Child](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0062971557\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Break in Case of Emergency](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F110191193X\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20).” She lives with her children in western Previously, he was the deputy editor of *Transition*, a journal of race and culture based at the W. E. B. Du Bois Research Institute at Harvard University. His writing has also appeared in a number of magazines and a handful of books, including “[Shake It Up: Great American Writing on Rock and Pop from Elvis to Jay Rosner is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*. She has been covering food for more than a decade as a writer and editor, and has received multiple James Beard Awards, including, in 2025, for her [Profile of the food personality Padma Lakshmi](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fprofiles\u002Fpadma-lakshmi-walks-into-a-bar), and, in 2024, for her weekly restaurant-review column, [The Food Scene](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Ffood-scene). In 2022, Rosner was a National Magazine Award finalist, for pieces on [how to cook with a microwave](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fkitchen-notes\u002Flearning-to-love-my-microwave), the CNN series “[Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fthe-timeless-fantasy-of-stanley-tucci-eating-italian-food),” and [how to get a table at Carbone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fhow-to-get-a-table-at-carbone). Rosner has worked at *Saveur* and *New York* magazine, launched the seminal food site Eat Me Daily, and served as a cookbook editor. Before joining *The New Yorker*, she was the executive editor of Eater, where she founded the publication’s James Beard- and National Magazine Award-winning features ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"5e7bc3aeba0e6f0009421c5b","filename":"RachelSyme.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F25\u002F5e7bc3aece97b85da38b2206_RachelSyme.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Syme, a staff writer, has covered Hollywood, theatre, fashion, television, literature, style, and other cultural subjects for *The New Yorker* since 2012. Her contributions include profiles of the actors [Carol Burnett](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2025\u002F10\u002F06\u002Fcarol-burnett-profile), [Natasha Lyonne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F11\u002Fin-russian-doll-natasha-lyonne-barrels-into-the-past), [Adam Scott](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fadam-scott-profile), and [Sarah Jessica Parker](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F06\u002F26\u002Fsarah-jessica-parker-profile); the director [Sofia Coppola](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fsofia-coppola-profile); the fashion designer [Thom Browne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F09\u002F25\u002Fhow-thom-brownes-gray-suit-conquered-american-fashion); the Netflix executive [Bela Bajaria](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F01\u002F16\u002Fhow-much-more-netflix-can-the-world-absorb-bela-bajaria); the theatre director [Rachel Chavkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fbehind-the-scenes-of-a-short-lived-broadway-musical); the perfumer [Francis Kurkdjian](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F09\u002F23\u002Ffrancis-kurkdjian-perfume-baccarat-rouge); the [creators of “PEN15”](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fthe-women-behind-the-thirteen-year-olds-of-pen15); and the [makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F07\u002Fback-to-school-with-mario-dedivanovic); an homage to the food writer [Laurie Colwin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F18\u002Flaurie-colwins-recipe-for-being-yourself-in-the-kitchen); a look into [Nora Ephron](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F08\u002F22\u002Fthe-nora-ephron-we-forget)’s verbal prowess; an essay on the rise of [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F11\u002F27\u002Fmy-name-is-barbra-streisand-memoir-review); an exploration of “[bathfluencers](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fon-and-off-the-avenue\u002Fthe-age-of-bathfluence)”; an interactive feature on [the art of the Hollywood memoir](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Fpage-turner\u002Fcelebrity-memoirs-book-reviews); conversations with [Lena Dunham](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Flena-dunhams-change-of-pace), [Jamie Lee Curtis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fjamie-lee-curtis-has-never-worked-hard-a-day-in-her-life), [Rick Steves](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Frick-steves-says-hold-on-to-your-travel-dreams), [Kate Berlant](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fkate-berlant-has-nothing-to-confess), [Parker Posey](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fparker-posey-is-dead-serious), [Patti LuPone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fpatti-lupone-live-from-her-basement), [Mandy Patinkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fmandy-patinkin-is-still-singing), and [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fbarbra-streisand-can-hear-herself-again); and short profiles of [Kirsten Dunst](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fkirsten-dunsts-feminine-urges), [Cynthia Nixon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fcynthia-nixons-emily-thing), and [Anna Deavere Smith](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fanna-deavere-smith-contains-multitudes). She is a regular contributor to the magazine’s On and Off the Avenue column.\n\nSyme’s cultural criticism and reported features, which focus primarily on the intersections of women’s lives, artistic production, history, and fame, have also appeared in the *Times Magazine*, *New York*, *Vogue*, *Rolling Stone*, and *Vanity Fair*, among other publications. She is the author of “[Syme’s Letter Writer](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSymes-Letter-Writer-Correspondence-Imaginable\u002Fdp\u002F059323510X)” (2025), about the joys of handwritten correspondence, and the narrative-nonfiction work “Magpie” (2026). His column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), examines the people and platforms shaping the Internet. His books include “[Filterworld: How Algorithms Flattened Culture](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281).” ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"60d4ac8925fa556303904def","filename":"kyle_chayka.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2021\u002F06\u002F24\u002F60d4ac8925fa556303904dee_kyle_chayka.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Kyle Chayka is a staff writer at *The New Yorker* covering technology and Internet culture. In his column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), he has explored why [the Internet isn’t fun anymore](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fwhy-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore), examined whether [A.I. art steals from artists](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fis-ai-art-stealing-from-artists), and covered [TikTok’s role in the vibes revival](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fcultural-comment\u002Ftiktok-and-the-vibes-revival). Chayka, who first contributed to *The New Yorker* in 2013, has also written for *The New Republic*, the New York *Times Magazine*, and *Harper’s*, among other publications. His reporting on tourism in Iceland was included in “[The Best American Travel Writing 2020](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FBest-American-Travel-Writing-2020\u002Fdp\u002F0358362032).” Chayka’s first nonfiction book, “[The Longing for Less](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLonging-Less-Living-Minimalism\u002Fdp\u002F163557210X),” a history of minimalism, was published in 2020. His second book, “[Filterworld](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=2TWV5H73GY78G&keywords=filterworld+book&qid=1706824552&sprefix=filterworld+book%2Caps%2C259&sr=8-1),” which explores the impact of digital algorithms on culture, was published in 2024. Chayka began his career in 2010, as a visual-art critic for the Web site Aviv","title":"Rachel Aviv is a staff writer at The New Yorker. She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. She is a former writer for “Saturday Night Live” and “Rugrats.” Her books include the novels “[Him Her Him Again the End of Him](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0743296249\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Starting from Happy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1439101299\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” both of which were finalists for the Thurber Prize; numerous children’s books, among them “[Now Everybody Really Hates Me](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0064434400\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=2&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Meet My Staff](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0060274840\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=3&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[Tired Town](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FTired-Town-Patricia-Marx\u002Fdp\u002F1250859123\u002F)”; and nonfiction books, including “[Let’s Be Less Stupid: An Attempt to Maintain My Mental Faculties](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1455554960\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=4&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” “[Why Don’t You Write My Eulogy Now So I Can Correct It?: A Mother’s Suggestions](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F1250301963\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=5&imprToken=84b9922e-8157-3377-f51&tag=thneyo0f-20),” and “[You Can Only Yell at Me for One Thing at a Time: Rules for Couples](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FYou-Only-Yell-Thing-Time\u002Fdp\u002F1250225132),” illustrated by Roz Chast.\n\nMarx was the first woman elected to the *Harvard Lampoon*. She has taught screenwriting and humor writing at Princeton University, New York University, Columbia, and Stonybrook University, but mainly she does errands and looks things up on Wikipedia. She was the recipient of a 2015 Guggenheim Fellowship. His book “[FilmCraft: Editing](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilmCraft-Editing-Justin-Chang\u002Fdp\u002F0240818644)” was published in 2011. Chang serves as the chair of the National Society of Film Critics and the secretary of the Los Angeles Film Critics Association, and is a member of the New York Film Festival selection committee. He teaches at the Annenberg School for Communication and Journalism at the University of Southern California.
