For his column, [The Front Row](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row), he has reviewed blockbusters, such as “[Top Gun: Maverick](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Ftop-gun-maverick-reviewed-tom-cruise-takes-empty-thrills-to-new-heights)”; international movies, such as “[Parasite](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-parasite-falls-short-of-greatness)”; independent films, including “[Lady Bird](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Frichard-brody\u002Fgreta-gerwigs-exquisite-flawed-lady-bird)”; and documentaries, such as “[Let It Be](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fhow-hindsight-distorts-our-view-of-the-beatles-in-let-it-be),” the 1970 film about the Beatles. His roundups have included the [best performances of the twenty-first century](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fthe-best-movie-performances-of-the-century-so-far) and the [best documentaries of all time](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-front-row\u002Fsixty-two-films-that-shaped-the-art-of-documentary-filmmaking). Brody has also contributed articles about directors such as [Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpostscript\u002Fjean-luc-godard-was-cinemas-north-star) and [Wes Anderson](http:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2009\u002F11\u002F02\u002Fwild-wild-wes). He is the author of the book “[Everything Is Cinema: The Working Life of Jean-Luc Godard](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0805080155)” and is at work on a book about the lasting influence of the French New Wave.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"tnyfrontrow","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"2025-in-review","name":"2025 in Review"},"channels":[{"name":"2025 in Review"},{"name":"The Current Cinema"},{"name":"The Front Row"}],"hed":"The Best Films of 2025","dek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","promoHed":"The Best Films of 2025","promoDek":"Our critics rank their favorite movies of the year.","url":"culture\u002F2025-in-review\u002Fthe-best-films-of-2025","rubric":"","lede":{"bookMarkedUrl":"https:\u002F\u002Fmedia.newyorker.com\u002Fphotos\u002F693208dc342b18a8b4bf3297\u002Fmaster\u002Fpass\u002FBest%20Movies%201%20(1).gif","altText":"Animation of a film reel rolling down film. For *The New Yorker*, Winter has [reported](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-the-life-of-the-mother-might-mean-in-a-post-roe-america) [extensively](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fthe-supreme-court-decision-that-defined-abortion-rights-for-thirty-years) on the [landscape](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fnews-desk\u002Fthe-dobbs-decision-has-unleashed-legal-chaos-for-doctors-and-patients) for [reproductive rights](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fthe-fight-over-ivf-is-only-beginning) in the U.S. after the [overturning](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fdaily-comment\u002Fwhats-missing-from-the-drafted-decision-to-overturn-roe-v-wade) of Roe v. Wade, and frequently contributes essays on books, culture, and current affairs. She has written about topics including [gentle parenting](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Funder-review\u002Fthe-harsh-realm-of-gentle-parenting), [middle-school culture wars](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-meltdown-at-a-middle-school-in-a-liberal-town), [early literacy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Fthe-rise-and-fall-of-vibes-based-literacy), [queer children’s books](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnews\u002Fannals-of-education\u002Flgbt-books-kids-ban), and [postpartum psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fscience\u002Fannals-of-medicine\u002Fwhat-we-still-dont-understand-about-postpartum-psychosis). Winter is the author of the novels “[The Fourth Child](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002Fdp\u002F0062971557\u002F?ots=1&slotNum=1&imprToken=58bfc4ec-96a6-c1fb-648&tag=thneyo0f-20)” and “[Break in Rosner is a staff writer at *The New Yorker*. She has been covering food for more than a decade as a writer and editor, and has received multiple James Beard Awards, including, in 2025, for her [Profile of the food personality Padma Lakshmi](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fprofiles\u002Fpadma-lakshmi-walks-into-a-bar), and, in 2024, for her weekly restaurant-review column, [The Food Scene](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fnewsletter\u002Ffood-scene). In 2022, Rosner was a National Magazine Award finalist, for pieces on [how to cook with a microwave](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fkitchen-notes\u002Flearning-to-love-my-microwave), the CNN series “[Stanley Tucci: Searching for Italy](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fthe-timeless-fantasy-of-stanley-tucci-eating-italian-food),” and [how to get a table at Carbone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fannals-of-gastronomy\u002Fhow-to-get-a-table-at-carbone). Rosner has worked at *Saveur* and *New York* magazine, launched the seminal food site Eat Me Daily, and served as a cookbook editor. Before joining *The New Yorker*, she was the executive editor of Eater, where she founded the publication’s James Beard- and National Magazine Award-winning features ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"5e7bc3aeba0e6f0009421c5b","filename":"RachelSyme.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2020\u002F03\u002F25\u002F5e7bc3aece97b85da38b2206_RachelSyme.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Syme, a staff writer, has covered Hollywood, theatre, fashion, television, literature, style, and other cultural subjects for *The New Yorker* since 2012. Her contributions include profiles of the actors [Carol Burnett](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2025\u002F10\u002F06\u002Fcarol-burnett-profile), [Natasha Lyonne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F11\u002Fin-russian-doll-natasha-lyonne-barrels-into-the-past), [Adam Scott](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Fadam-scott-profile), and [Sarah Jessica Parker](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F06\u002F26\u002Fsarah-jessica-parker-profile); the director [Sofia Coppola](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F01\u002F29\u002Fsofia-coppola-profile); the fashion designer [Thom Browne](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F09\u002F25\u002Fhow-thom-brownes-gray-suit-conquered-american-fashion); the Netflix executive [Bela Bajaria](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F01\u002F16\u002Fhow-much-more-netflix-can-the-world-absorb-bela-bajaria); the theatre director [Rachel Chavkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F06\u002F03\u002Fbehind-the-scenes-of-a-short-lived-broadway-musical); the perfumer [Francis Kurkdjian](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F09\u002F23\u002Ffrancis-kurkdjian-perfume-baccarat-rouge); the [creators of “PEN15”](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F12\u002F06\u002Fthe-women-behind-the-thirteen-year-olds-of-pen15); and the [makeup artist Mario Dedivanovic](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2020\u002F09\u002F07\u002Fback-to-school-with-mario-dedivanovic); an homage to the food writer [Laurie Colwin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F10\u002F18\u002Flaurie-colwins-recipe-for-being-yourself-in-the-kitchen); a look into [Nora Ephron](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F08\u002F22\u002Fthe-nora-ephron-we-forget)’s verbal prowess; an essay on the rise of [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2023\u002F11\u002F27\u002Fmy-name-is-barbra-streisand-memoir-review); an exploration of “[bathfluencers](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fon-and-off-the-avenue\u002Fthe-age-of-bathfluence)”; an interactive feature on [the art of the Hollywood memoir](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fbooks\u002Fpage-turner\u002Fcelebrity-memoirs-book-reviews); conversations with [Lena Dunham](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Flena-dunhams-change-of-pace), [Jamie Lee Curtis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fjamie-lee-curtis-has-never-worked-hard-a-day-in-her-life), [Rick Steves](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Frick-steves-says-hold-on-to-your-travel-dreams), [Kate Berlant](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fkate-berlant-has-nothing-to-confess), [Parker Posey](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fparker-posey-is-dead-serious), [Patti LuPone](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fpatti-lupone-live-from-her-basement), [Mandy Patinkin](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fmandy-patinkin-is-still-singing), and [Barbra Streisand](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fthe-new-yorker-interview\u002Fbarbra-streisand-can-hear-herself-again); and short profiles of [Kirsten Dunst](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fkirsten-dunsts-feminine-urges), [Cynthia Nixon](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fcynthia-nixons-emily-thing), and [Anna Deavere Smith](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fpersons-of-interest\u002Fanna-deavere-smith-contains-multitudes). She is a regular contributor to the magazine’s On and Off the Avenue column.\n\nSyme’s cultural criticism and reported features, which focus primarily on the intersections of women’s lives, artistic production, history, and fame, have also appeared in the *Times Magazine*, *New York*, *Vogue*, *Rolling Stone*, and *Vanity Fair*, among other publications. She is the author of “[Syme’s Letter Writer](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FSymes-Letter-Writer-Correspondence-Imaginable\u002Fdp\u002F059323510X)” (2025), about the joys of handwritten correspondence, and the narrative-nonfiction work “Magpie” (2026). His books include “[Filterworld: How Algorithms Flattened Culture](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281).” ","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"60d4ac8925fa556303904def","filename":"kyle_chayka.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2021\u002F06\u002F24\u002F60d4ac8925fa556303904dee_kyle_chayka.png"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Kyle Chayka is a staff writer at *The New Yorker* covering technology and Internet culture. In his column, [Infinite Scroll](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll), he has explored why [the Internet isn’t fun anymore](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fwhy-the-internet-isnt-fun-anymore), examined whether [A.I. art steals from artists](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Finfinite-scroll\u002Fis-ai-art-stealing-from-artists), and covered [TikTok’s role in the vibes revival](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fculture\u002Fcultural-comment\u002Ftiktok-and-the-vibes-revival). Chayka, who first contributed to *The New Yorker* in 2013, has also written for *The New Republic*, the New York *Times Magazine*, and *Harper’s*, among other publications. His reporting on tourism in Iceland was included in “[The Best American Travel Writing 2020](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FBest-American-Travel-Writing-2020\u002Fdp\u002F0358362032).” Chayka’s first nonfiction book, “[The Longing for Less](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FLonging-Less-Living-Minimalism\u002Fdp\u002F163557210X),” a history of minimalism, was published in 2020. His second book, “[Filterworld](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FFilterworld-How-Algorithms-Flattened-Culture\u002Fdp\u002F0385548281\u002Fref=sr_1_1?crid=2TWV5H73GY78G&keywords=filterworld+book&qid=1706824552&sprefix=filterworld+book%2Caps%2C259&sr=8-1),” which explores the impact of digital algorithms on culture, was published in 2024. Chayka began his career in 2010, as a visual-art critic for the Web site She is the author of “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848),” a finalist for the 2022 National Book Critics Circle Award.","type":"AUTHOR","contributorType":"AUTHOR","photo":{"id":"62b9f7587abdd44987a402e0","filename":"Screen Shot 2022-05-23 at 6.17.20 PM.png","aspectRatios":[{"url":"https:\u002F\u002Fgp-prd-global-clips-s3.s3.amazonaws.com\u002Fpublic\u002Ftny-services\u002Fproduction\u002F2022\u002F06\u002F27\u002F62b9f7587abdd44987a402df_Screen%20Shot%202022-05-23%20at%206.17.20%20PM.png"},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null},{"url":null}],"metadata":{"contentType":"photo"}},"bio":"Rachel Aviv joined *The New Yorker* as a staff writer in 2013, covering mental health, ethics, and criminal justice. Her subjects have included the writer [Alice Munro](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F12\u002F30\u002Falice-munros-passive-voice) and her daughter’s experience trying to break the silence surrounding her sexual abuse, in a report that received a 2024 George Polk Award; [Lucy Letby](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2024\u002F05\u002F20\u002Flucy-letby-was-found-guilty-of-killing-seven-babies-did-she-do-it), a neonatal nurse who may have been wrongfully convicted of murder; a German experiment that [placed foster children with pedophiles](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F07\u002F26\u002Fthe-german-experiment-that-placed-foster-children-with-pedophiles); and the psychologist [Elizabeth Loftus](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2021\u002F04\u002F05\u002Fhow-elizabeth-loftus-changed-the-meaning-of-memory), in a Profile that received a National Magazine Award in 2022.\n\nAviv has also written about [medical ethics](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2018\u002F02\u002F05\u002Fwhat-does-it-mean-to-die), [psychosis](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2011\u002F05\u002F30\u002Fgod-knows-where-i-am), crime, and [education](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2022\u002F04\u002F04\u002Fmackenzie-fierceton-rhodes-scholarship-university-of-pennsylvania). She received the 2015 Scripps Howard Award for her investigation of [police shootings in Albuquerque](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fmagazine\u002F2015\u002F02\u002F02\u002Fson-deceased), and her writing on mental health has been honored with the American Psychoanalytic Association Award for Excellence in Journalism, among other distinctions. She has twice been a finalist for the National Magazine Award for Public Interest, and she was a 2019 national fellow at New America. Aviv was a recipient of the Whiting Creative Nonfiction Grant for her 2022 book, “[Strangers to Ourselves: Unsettled Minds and the Stories That Make Us](https:\u002F\u002Fwww.amazon.com\u002FStrangers-Ourselves-Unsettled-Minds-Stories\u002Fdp\u002F0374600848\u002Fref=tmm_hrd_swatch_0?ots=1&slotNum=0&imprToken=bcc2c3d9-9ae4-d6fe-7db&tag=thneyo0f-20&linkCode=w50&_encoding=UTF8&qid=1661968243&sr=8-1),” which became a finalist for the National Book Critics Circle Award, and which the *Times* and the *Wall Street Journal* named one of the ten best books of the year. She lives in Brooklyn.","socialMedia":[{"handle":"rachelaviv","network":"Twitter"}],"metadata":{"contentType":"contributor"}}}]},"channel":{"slug":"a-reporter-at-large","name":"A Reporter at Large"},"channels":[{"name":"A Reporter at Large"},{"name":"New Yorker Favorites"}],"hed":"How an Ivy League School Turned Against a Student","dek":"Mackenzie Fierceton was championed as a former foster youth who had overcome an abusive childhood and won a prestigious Rhodes Scholarship. Chakrabarty, who had recently completed a Ph.D. at Columbia University, shared passages written by prominent authors, such as the Nobel laureate ",["a",{"href":"https:\u002F\u002Fwww.newyorker.com\u002Fcontributors\u002Fhan-kang","isExternal":false},"Han Kang"],", with leading large language models. Then he fed them a description of a specific scene (which he hadn’t shared) and asked the models to generate it in the author’s style. In blind tests, the students consistently hated the A.I.-generated writing. The L.L.M.s were losing."]],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Chakrabarty and his collaborator Paramveer Dhillon, a University of Michigan professor, wondered if the A.I. output would improve if they fine-tuned GPT-4o, the model that powered ChatGPT at the time, by feeding it an author’s entire œuvre. One night in April, Chakrabarty was in Tokyo on vacation, jet-lagged and bored in his hotel, and he pushed almost all of Han’s translated writings into the model. I won’t enlist A.I. to write on my behalf for the same reason that I won’t enlist a robot to do other hard stuff—hike a mountain, argue with my husband. But, lately, I’ve been pushing up against the limitations of that logic. I can write a book for my own reasons, but I can ",["em","sell"]," the book only if readers like it more than what they can get from, say, a chatbot. This suggested that anyone with some storytelling skills could feed a plot into a fine-tuned chatbot, slap their name on the resulting manuscript, and try to publish it. People often minimize A.I.-generated literature—after all, we read books to access someone else’s consciousness. But what if we can’t tell the difference? When Chakrabarty returned from Japan, he invited Jane Ginsburg, a Columbia professor who specializes in copyright law, to join him and Dhillon as a co-author of a paper about the research. There was no way that a large language model could have seen them before."]],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"The narrator of my novel in progress is an Indian American ex-journalist. Chakrabarty used an L.L.M. to create content summaries of the excerpts I’d sent him. (One representative sentence, from a summary about the narrator’s journaling habit, explains, “A pivotal memory is introduced: in ninth grade, the narrator’s mother read this journal, an act seen as a profound betrayal.”) Finally, he gave the summaries to his fine-tuned model, and he asked it to compose passages “in the style of Vauhini Vara.”"],["p",{"class":"paywall"},"Going into all this, I was self-assured, even smug. I figured that, even if the A.I. model could imitate my past books, it couldn’t predict the style of the novel in progress. So, when Chakrabarty sent me the A.I.-generated imitations, I was genuinely confused. Like Díaz and Nunez, I found lots of stylistic details—rhythm, verbiage—annoying. But the text produced by the model was eerily close to mine. Reading some of its lines next to my own, I couldn’t remember which was which. Unlike Díaz or Nunez, I even preferred some of the doppelgänger’s versions. But is that true? When I was younger, I used to keep a journal for myself; I didn’t want anyone else to ever read it, which meant I didn’t need to describe the people and places I was writing about or explain why they mattered. When my mom did read my journal, in the ninth grade, I considered it the biggest betrayal I’d ever experienced, but the saving grace was knowing that she could not have possibly understood most of what I was writing about. I had an audience of one: myself."],["div",{"class":"paywall heading-h6","role":"heading","aria-level":"6"},"But when I write as an adult, I keep having the impulse to explain everything, as if I’m imagining an addressee who isn’t me. In journalism, we talk about the importance of writing for a mass audience—the adage that sticks with me is to write so that a third-grader can understand, though I can’t remember where I picked that up. Maybe something happens in the transition from childhood to adulthood to widen our scope, such that we no longer see the appeal in telling stories for ourselves."]]],["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"accordion-item","attrs":{"opened":"true"},"childTypes":["callout:accordion-header","callout:accordion-panel"]},"ref":"","type":"callout:accordion-item"},["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"accordion-header","attrs":{},"childTypes":[]},"ref":"","type":"callout:accordion-header"},["p",{"class":"paywall"},["strong","II. We’d both spent many years creating something that we cared deeply about—I with my journalism, she with her startup—and then gone on to focus on empowering others to do the same. She said she’d been surprised to find that mentoring other founders was even more meaningful than running her own startup; in business terms, the R.O.I. was higher, if you were willing to count fulfillment as a return. Rather than putting all her energy into her own startup, she could become a venture capitalist and invest somewhat less of it into many companies. In the terminology, she’d be building an interconnected ecosystem, such that one business could help another. That’s where the name of her new firm, ANIMAL CAPITAL, came from. It was an allusion to the fact that we, as animals, are interdependent with one another. She asked me if artists used the term ecosystem. I said we don’t use that particular business metaphor, but only because we haven’t raised a Series A. In principle, it’s the same. That we learn from and depend on one another is central to most artists’ work."]]],["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"accordion-item","attrs":{"opened":"true"},"childTypes":["callout:accordion-header","callout:accordion-panel"]},"ref":"","type":"callout:accordion-item"},["inline-embed",{"props":{"name":"accordion-header","attrs":{},"childTypes":[]},"ref":"","type":"callout:accordion-header"},["p",{"class":"paywall"},["strong","III. I was reassured by the experiment’s limits, as well. Even if the A.I. model could create prose that passed for mine, that didn’t mean it could invent the content.
